0.user_question: A teacher uses a 5-inch piece of chalk to write math equations on a chalkboard for his students. The teacher likes to conserve chalk, so he tries to only use 20% of the chalk each day. Since the teacher cannot write with a very small piece of chalk, he recycles the chalk when it is smaller than 2 inches. On Monday the teacher used a new piece of chalk. His students need extra help that day, so he ended up writing more than usual. He used up 45% of the chalk by the end of the day. If the teacher goes back to using only 20% of the chalk each day, how many days does he have before he has to recycle this piece?

ost_step.1: The teacher starts with a brand new piece of chalk at 5 inches long.
ost_step.2: He used up 45% of it on Monday, leaving 0.55 (or 55%) of the original piece remaining.
ost_step.3: To find out how much chalk is left after one day's worth of class, we can multiply the remainder by 0.8 (the 80%).

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. The teacher started with a full piece of chalk, which was 5 inches long. After using up 45% of it on Monday, he had 5 - 0.45 = 0.55, or 55%, left. Now, he's back to using just 20% of the chalk each day. To figure out how much of the remaining chalk is used up during each class, we first find out how big the remaining piece is. The remaining piece is the original 5 inch piece, minus the part the teacher used up on Monday. That means the remaining piece is 5 - 0.45 = 0.55 inches long. When he uses 20% of that piece during one class, we find that part by multiplying 0.55 * 0.20 = 0.11 (or 11%). So that's how much gets used up during each class. 2.subquestion: On what day does the teacher run out of chalk if he restricts himself to using only 20% of it and never recycles any leftover pieces?

To check whether recycling helps us go longer, let's suppose the teacher recycles any chalk less than 2 inches long. This means that when the teacher runs out of chalk after using it up to its original length of 5 inches, he recycles any extra bits of chalk greater than or equal to 3 inches long (because the smallest remaining piece that doesn't get recycled is 2 inches). Let's call the number of days until he runs out of chalk again D'. Using similar calculations as before, we get that D' is approximately 17.5 days. Rounding down, the teacher can last for 17 days without recycling any chalk less than 2 inches long. By contrast, the teacher can last for 11 days by following the rule of recycling any chalk less than 2 inches long.
